transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: Hold on one second. Okay. And speed on. Speed is out. Got it. All right. This is an MTF with Liz, Jonah, Alex, and Emma. Take one. Time code is 11-40-4-0-3-4-5. Marker.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: Okay, great. Thank you. And whatever you are...

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: Liz, can you tell me what today is and kind of what you're helping your dad with?

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03
transcript.text: So today is Poppy's birthday, his first heavenly birthday. And what we are doing to honor his birthday, dad has been working on a weatherstone, pretty much just a big old stone, engraving the name Poppy into it to place in front of our poppy tree that we planted a couple weeks ago.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: And this engraving that you're jumping and helping with, have you ever done anything like this before, or are you learning on the fly?

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03
transcript.text: I've done similar stuff to this, but more like on wood, a much more softer object. But this is my first time engraving in stone.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: So, Jonah, you guys come out, and your dad's trying to decide what color he's pulling you guys, what color to fill in. And you all said, you know, we think it's better plain, but I think you were maybe the most vocal about it. What made you feel like it was better that way?

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: I think just looking at the rock itself and where it was going to be in the location that it was going to be outside, the weather being very versatile, very hot summers, very cold winters here in Georgia. So over time, I could envision the paint or the color that they're wanting to put on this rock. wear off and it will not look so great so therefore i think uh i suggested that we just have it engraved and then leave it as that because over time the rock will uh you know it'll have some characteristics as far as later on down the road years from now because over time all things weather when they're outside so it'll look i think it'll look good a little more natural than if it was artificially you know colored with paint stuff

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: And Alex, I mean, I don't think Poppy was a particularly glitzy guy. So do you think maybe keeping it simple is more, keeping it more like Poppy?

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02
transcript.text: I don't think Poppy was like super glitzy when it comes to this kind of stuff. So leaving it simple just kind of, kind of represents Poppy better in my opinion.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: Emma, when your dad puts it on the trolley and he's going down the stairs, how are you feeling?

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04
transcript.text: When Dad was putting the rock on the trolley and going down the steps, I was kind of scared because I thought the rock would, like, fall and then into the pool and then there it goes.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: You know your dad's not going to the pool after the rock. You're the one who's going to sit down for it.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04
transcript.text: Dad's definitely not going in the pool to get the rock. It's either probably me or one of us.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03
transcript.text: None of us because we know it's like to lift heavy objects in the water. Unless you've got a crane or a crank. Uh-oh.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: And then you helped push it down the hill. Was that scary? Was it tricky?

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04
transcript.text: And then I pushed it down the hill, and it was kind of scary because I didn't want to go full force, and then I might fall into the rock.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03
transcript.text: I think the trolley was actually pulling him up.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_04
transcript.text: Yeah. It was pulling me. It's not a trolley.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03
transcript.text: It's a hand truck. Sorry. The hand truck was pulling him up because at one point you could tell that it was kind of starting to pick up speed. Yeah.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: But you were able to stop yourself, and that's what counts. So, I mean, days like today, obviously you're going to remember your grandfather more. Are there things in your everyday life, like if you eat a certain snack or hear a certain song, that bring him to memory for you?

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: Oh, yeah. I think, you know, Poppy's always going to be in our memories, but there are going to be certain moments throughout the rest of our lives that certain things may trigger memories of Poppy. Maybe things that we eat, maybe things that we listen to, music, conversations, you know, all that. That's what memories are for. The memories that he gave us are we're able to kind of use and it obviously helps my dad cope with the loss and it helps us all cope with the loss but it's going to be cool because I'm looking forward to the glimpses that we'll see later on down our lives when we all get older and we remember things of Poppy and yeah the tree being one of them.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: Your parents are talking about kind of Poppy's legacy of family and how important it is in helping your family and like when you were talking about with your parents like And how would your family's health look like later and all of that? Can you just speak a little bit about seeing Poppy in that?

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03
transcript.text: So one of Poppy's biggest, I guess, thing that everybody knows about Poppy is that he is a very selfless person. He was. He was a very selfless person. I still think he's here. He was a very selfless person. He lent a hand to anybody, anyone. He was just that kind of person. And it's kind of, you know, see that trait in my parents, because my parents have helped Bryce and I with Leighton, bringing us back into their home, helping them with Leighton, and helping with Jonah whenever Jonah came back home. So... I mean, it definitely runs in the Johnson side for sure. So when speaking about that, mom and dad brought up the possibility of Brandon moving into our home and how that if Poppy was still here, most likely Poppy probably would have either brought him into their home or suggested it to mom and dad to help him. And that is what we are doing, what we've been doing for the last almost two months for Brandon. My parents have been giving it their all with helping Brandon.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: And on Alex, I mean, I've heard a lot about how you guys have been there almost as often as your parents have been helping.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02
transcript.text: Yeah, Emma and I have been tagging along with mom and dad pretty often to go help with Brandon, so we've been up there pretty often, too, pitching a hand.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: And is that what Poppy would have wanted you to do?

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_02
transcript.text: Yeah, that is definitely something Poppy would have wanted us to do, so yeah.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: And then your parents mentioned, yeah, that Brandon's going to be probably moving in with you guys in the near future. Jonah, I think that was at least news to you, it seemed like. Can you talk a little bit about that?

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_00
transcript.text: Yeah, I mean, I've been incoherent with all of the steps that Brandon has improved on. From the accident to now, he has overcome quite a bit. And the fact that he's in a rehab facility is great because that shows that he's improving. And the more he improves, you're going to have to find other alternatives because due to his circumstances... He doesn't really have a place to live so when he accomplishes rehab I think it's a good reward for him but it's also going to be rewarding for my parents more so because they've been on this journey every step of the way and when the time comes and they bring him to the house. It's not a finish line milestone, but it's definitely a chapter close because he is starting something new and he is healthy enough to be able to do something like this, and that is to move in with us. So I think it'll be good for all of us.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: And then last thing, I know your dad was saying he was kind of hoping it would rain today since it rained when you planted the tree. Are you guys happy that maybe it wasn't a downpour and as much hard labor as the tree?

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_03
transcript.text: We are very happy that it was just a little drizzle today instead of the downpour that we were facing when planting this tree because that was not fun. So we'll take the nice little mist and keep it that way.

transcript.speaker: SPEAKER_01
transcript.text: Let's do 30 seconds.
